summary: I’ve thought a lot about it, and I think I figured out why Michael Sheen as Aziraphale has bothered me since the first time I...
body: I’ve thought a lot about it, and I think I figured out why Michael Sheen as Aziraphale has bothered me since the first time I saw him in costume - he’s so good at playing this character with no guile, no pretext, wearing his heart on his sleeve and all over his face.  And after all, shouldn’t an angel feel their feelings purely and without some sort of subterfuge?  But it’s hard for me to watch, it’s hard for me to appreciate the sweet smile and big eyes, especially when those are pointed at Crowley, because to me that seems dangerous.  Being soft, being vulnerable, that’s how people get hurt.  If you play things close to the vest, if you hide behind dark glasses or swagger or attitude, you can protect yourself.  Tennant is so much fun to watch as Crowley A) because he gives off serious Bill Nighy in Love Actually vibes, and B) because he mostly doesn’t show real human emotion, except for anger.  I can’t watch Aziraphale love Crowley purely because I’ve tried most of my adult life to hide any feelings I’ve had like that, about anything.  But Sheen and this character making me feel uncomfortable is a good thing, because I need to challenge all those years I spent trying to put up walls and embrace the soft and the vulnerable.  The ability to love purely, it’s the most divine thing about humans.

summary: Good Omens Easter eggs/easily missed moments, EP 6.
title: Good Omens Easter eggs/easily missed moments, EP 6.
body:
1. Pepper’s line “I believe in peace, bitch” is a Tori Amos reference. It’s a line from her song Waitress. Tori Amos and Neil Gaiman have been friends for over 30 years.

2. Aziraphale & Crowley are literally an angel & demon on Adam’s shoulders.

3. The shop to the right of Aziraphale’s shop is called ‘Bilton Scaggs: Hats & Caps’, in the book Bilton & Scaggs is an unlucky publishing firm, who amongst other publishing disasters also happened to publish ‘The Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Agnes Nutter, Witch’. On Instagram Neil Gaiman said that in his personal headcanon “the publisher next door went out of business in the 1890s, and the milliner who moved in couldn’t afford a new shop sign. So it became Bilton and Scaggs Milliner & Haberdasher. And then, around 1965, they became Bilton Scaggs, and have remained such ever since. And only Aziraphale knows where the name comes from.”

4. An early clue to the body-swap is “Crowley” walking normally.

5. Another clue is that he says ‘tickety-boo’ when ambushed by the other demons.

6. The fact that Aziraphale buys actual clothes, and keeps them nicely forever, as apposed to Crowley just manifesting the trendy clothes of the era, will give a further clue here, as “Crowley” has taken off his clothes, so not to ruin them.

7. This is the Sky Garden in London, a fact I found nice, given the show’s theme of gardens.

8. Both David Tennant and Michael Sheen are doing brilliant impersonations of each other’s characters here, in both posture and voice.

9. Not easily missed but I wanted to include it.



[more Easter eggs]

summary: Good Omens Easter eggs/easily missed moments, Ep.5
title: Good Omens Easter eggs/easily missed moments, Ep.5
body:
1. As the music in this scene is coming from a gramophone in Aziraphale’s shop, the transformative effect of, over time, any music turning into The Best of Queen, seems to influence more than just the Bentley.

2. As Aziraphale has been discorporated, his clothes have been lost and he is now in blank, plain clothing.

3. When Crowley says that he lost his best friend, Aziraphale looks crestfallen. He doesn’t realise that Crowley is referring to him, because from his point of view he’s merely been discorporated, and knows nothing of the bookshop fire yet.

4. Death has all the scores on the leader board, except the top spot which is claimed by T.Pratchett. In a way it’s saying Terry beat Death.

5. A little nod back to the ‘invest in the Apple that can’t be eaten’ prophecy.

6. As Death walks away from the arcade machines, they change to say ‘Game Over’. Also, one of the biggest losses from the book are the other four bikers of the apocalypse, which were cut for budget & time reasons. If you’ve not read the book I’d encourage you to at least read the part about them! (Although, I’d actually encourage you read the whole thing!)

7. When Madame Tracey asks if there’s a Mr Scroggie at the seance, Mr Scroggie replies in a very Wensleydale way, by starting his sentence with ‘actually’. This implies something about both of their personalities.

8. This message on the cold-caller’s screen is a reference to this line in the book:

She was well in the lead in the office daily Getting People Out of the Bath stakes, and only needed two more points to win the weekly Coitus Interruptus award.

9. Though it’s never explicitly mentioned in the show, there are many callbacks to this line from the book:

…all tapes left in a car for more than about a fortnight metamorphose into Best of Queen albums.

Here for instance, you see Crowley put a Mozart CD into the car, and Mozart starts playing, but as the Bentley enters the M25 fire the music transforms into Queen’s “I’m In Love With My Car” 

10. Even though he’s just preformed a miracle and made the scooter fly, and they’re racing to Tadfield to prevent the apocalypse, Aziraphale still takes the time to pause and indicate before turning the corner.

11. The guard at the air base is reading Neil Gaiman’s American Gods.

12. Earlier Pepper was angrily complaining about being given a ‘girls bike with a basket’, here it seems that Adam swapped with her to make her happy. Also Brian’s bike is filthy because of course it is.



[more Easter eggs]

trail.content:
1. As the music in this scene is coming from a gramophone in Aziraphale’s shop, the transformative effect of, over time, any music turning into The Best of Queen, seems to influence more than just the Bentley.

2. As Aziraphale has been discorporated, his clothes have been lost and he is now in blank, plain clothing.

3. When Crowley says that he lost his best friend, Aziraphale looks crestfallen. He doesn’t realise that Crowley is referring to him, because from his point of view he’s merely been discorporated, and knows nothing of the bookshop fire yet.

4. Death has all the scores on the leader board, except the top spot which is claimed by T.Pratchett. In a way it’s saying Terry beat Death.

5. A little nod back to the ‘invest in the Apple that can’t be eaten’ prophecy.

6. As Death walks away from the arcade machines, they change to say ‘Game Over’. Also, one of the biggest losses from the book are the other four bikers of the apocalypse, which were cut for budget & time reasons. If you’ve not read the book I’d encourage you to at least read the part about them! (Although, I’d actually encourage you read the whole thing!)

7. When Madame Tracey asks if there’s a Mr Scroggie at the seance, Mr Scroggie replies in a very Wensleydale way, by starting his sentence with ‘actually’. This implies something about both of their personalities.

8. This message on the cold-caller’s screen is a reference to this line in the book:

She was well in the lead in the office daily Getting People Out of the Bath stakes, and only needed two more points to win the weekly Coitus Interruptus award.

9. Though it’s never explicitly mentioned in the show, there are many callbacks to this line from the book:

…all tapes left in a car for more than about a fortnight metamorphose into Best of Queen albums.

Here for instance, you see Crowley put a Mozart CD into the car, and Mozart starts playing, but as the Bentley enters the M25 fire the music transforms into Queen’s “I’m In Love With My Car” 

10. Even though he’s just preformed a miracle and made the scooter fly, and they’re racing to Tadfield to prevent the apocalypse, Aziraphale still takes the time to pause and indicate before turning the corner.

11. The guard at the air base is reading Neil Gaiman’s American Gods.

12. Earlier Pepper was angrily complaining about being given a ‘girls bike with a basket’, here it seems that Adam swapped with her to make her happy. Also Brian’s bike is filthy because of course it is.



[more Easter eggs]

summary: Good Omens Easter eggs/easily missed moments, Ep. 4
title: Good Omens Easter eggs/easily missed moments, Ep. 4
body:
1. Brian states that aliens would say “Exerminate”, another Doctor Who reference.

2. Gabriel has angel wings on his jumper.

3. The demons who come from animals, have that animal’s eyes (and I think the animals on their heads have demon eyes?). Ligur has chameleon eyes, that change colour during scenes.

4. While deciding where to escape to, a page with Gallifrey on hovers behind Crowley. Another Doctor Who reference.

5. The delivery note for Death read:
Deliver to: Death
Location: Everywhere
Package: Say to him ‘come + see’.

6. The firelighters footnote is possibly my favourite from the book:

[Note for Americans and other city-dwelling life-forms: the rural British, having eschewed central heating as being far too complicated and in any case weakening moral fibre, prefer a system of piling small pieces of wood and lumps of coal, topped by large, wet logs, possibly made of asbestos, into small, smouldering heaps, known as “There’s nothing like a roaring open fire is there?” Since none of these ingredients are naturally inclined to burn, underneath all this they apply a small, rectangular, waxy white lump, which burns cheerfully until the weight of the fire puts it out. These little white blocks are called firelighters. No one knows why.]

7. The only other person in the cinema with Crowley is Neil Gaiman. “Not only will you see me passed out dead drunk in the audience, but all of the voices of the bunnies are me”.

8. This passerby is played by Dan Starkey, who played Strax & other Sontarans in Doctor Who.

9. Crowley’s safe combination appears to be 31-10-68, though it’s a little hard to make out. It’s 4-0-0-4 in the book, the year he came to Earth.

10. The “discrete gentlemen’s club in Portland Place in the late 1880s” may refer to the Hundred Guineas Club, a famous gay club of the time. Then again it may not.

11. The music shop beside Aziraphale’s bookshop is called ‘Vinyl Fetish’, a very Soho pun.

12. The exchange “You monster, seducing women to do your evil will”, “oh I think perhaps you’ve got the wrong shop”, appears to be another joke/hint about Aziraphale’s leanings, but it’s also a joke about Soho, “The Soho area has been at the heart of London’s sex industry for more than 200 years”.


[more Easter eggs]
